value: Lots of duplication of information between the two articles.

is a village located within the town of
.  The village initially grew up around an intersection of two railroad lines and trains frequently pass through the town.  Many buildings at the center of the village date back to the 19th century.

value: Main St. near Five Corners in Essex Jct VT
.  Essex Junction is only a few miles away from Burlington International Airport. Flights arrive daily via several carriers from as far away as

.  Travelers from farther afield will have to make a connection in a larger city. There are non-stop flights to Burlington Airport from the following cities (some cities may be seasonal or only offer service certain days of the week):
, 29 Railroad Ave. Daily 8AM-10PM. Service by Amtrak's Vermonter Line.

Routes 15, 117, and 2a will all bring you to the center of the village.
Essex Junction is small enough to be navigated on foot.
Cycling can be a good way to get around the village.  There are dedicated bike lanes on some streets and traffic moves at fairly low speeds,
The Essex Junction, Essex-Williston, and Essex Town routes of CCTA all serve the village, however they are more useful for getting to and from Essex Junction than getting around.
Essex Junction is easily navigable by car and there is ample parking.  The only problem you are likely to encounter is traffic at Five Corners during rush hour.

value: File:Railroad Ave, Essex Jct VT smaller.jpg
Railroad Ave. looking towards the Amtrak station

Admittedly, there isn't much here for the traveler to see.  From some parts of town you can get excellent views of Mt. Mansfield and Camel's Hump.  The rural parts of Essex offer pleasant landscapes, but these can be found all over Vermont. The older parts of town are fairly attractive, especially from late spring through fall, and that's about it.

value: directions=Off route 15 heading west towards Burlington.
content=This former military base has been converted into housing and commercial space.  There are many historic structures throughout the fort, especially surrounding the parade ground.

Essex is home to several golf courses and parks of interest as well as Vermont's busiest exposition center.  If you do end up in Essex, it's probably to see a concert or attend a fair of some kind.

value: content=Play a round of golf at one of the most affordable courses in the area while enjoying views of Mt. Mansfield and Camel's Hump.
Hike or mountain bike the trails around this reservoir. Swimming, canoeing, and fishing are also options.

Essex Junction is home to the Champlain Valley Fairgrounds.  Events and concerts are held at the facility year round.

value: price=Worlds only steeplechase for humans.  Held May 4-5
content=New England's largest quilt show is held from June 28-June 30
-Held at the fairgrounds in late August-early September, it is the state's largest fair.  In the warmer months, the fairgrounds hosts frequent concerts.
Entrance to the Champlain Valley Fairgrounds.  Contrary to the impression this photo might give, Essex Junction is not in Canada.  The American flag is just out of frame.

There are fewer shopping opportunities here than you might expect because the town isn't served by an interstate.  There are lots of stores that serve residents (hardware, grocery, and autopart stores), but not as many that would be of interest to travelers.

value: content=Local running shoe and apparel specialists.
content=Quilting supply, fabrics for traditional quilts.
name=Shawn Bushey Road Res Q Services
content=Auto repair shop at Five Corners.
content=Outlet mall containing stores like Orvis, Puma, Ralph Lauren, and Van Huesen. There's also a 9 screen cinema and several restaurants.
content=Founded in 2007 as a locally cafe and bookstore.

Essex has the typical suburban chains like McDonalds, Wendys, KFC, and the ubiquitous (in New England) Dunkin Donuts.  However most of the restaurants are one-off local places with much better food.  Most restaurants are lunch oriented due to the number of people who work in Essex, but most still serve dinner.

value: directions=Corner of Maple and Park Street at the 5 corners

content=Formerly the Lincoln Inn, this is an Essex Junction institution. They have live bands Wed-Sat. This is a great place to rub elbows with the locals. They have 28 beers on tap, including a good selection of Vermont beers.
content=Breakfast and lunch spot serving burritos, paninis,and omelettes.
content=Sandwich shop located at Five Corners.  Huge sandwiches as well as a few homemade side dishes. An Essex institution.
content=Popular pizza place with attached creamee stand
content=Small restaurant serving burgers, sandwiches, and a few dinner entrees.  Pictures of dogs on the walls and outdoor seating in the warmer months.
content=Entrees featuring local ingredients and award winning BBQ.

Essex, despite being the second largest municipality in Vermont, isn't a nightlife hotspot.  There isn't even a coffeeshop aside from Dunkin Donuts.  Most people looking for a drink or a night out will head into

value: content=Hard cider producer and tasting room.

That being said, Essex does have a few bars.  However, they are not quite like those in Burlington.  The presence of IBM and the transition to a bedroom community for office workers has transformed Essex into a town of suburban yuppies, but it wasn't always that way and the old rural/blue collar Essex still exists.  Unlike Burlington, most bars won't have an extensive list of microbrews, tasteful decorations, or rowdy college students.  What you will find are cheap American lagers, dingy bar rooms, darts, pool, and sometimes karaoke.  This is Northern Vermont, so you will always be able to find a Switchback if you don't like PBR and Rolling Rock.

For some reason, Essex only has two hotels, one of which is a luxury resort.  For most tourists, this won't be an issue as you will probably be staying elsewhere, however business travelers and people visiting relatives may have to stay in neighboring

value: content=The closest thing Vermont has to a home-grown hotel chain.
name=The Essex Culinary Resort and Spa
content=A pretty expensive resort with an attached spa and two restaurants.
